item.title: Create a Directus Project
item.description: Our first step is to structure our project. Throughout his guide we will add multiple workspaces to the project So we will start off by creating our root package.json: { "private": true, "workspaces": [ "directus-app" ] } And our directus-app/package.json: { "name": "directus-app", "version": "0.0.0", "license": "MIT" } Then we install directus: yarn workspace directus-app add directus To be able to run directus, we need a database to connect to. Let’s set up a postgres database using directus-app/docker-compose.

item.title: Commit Your Schema to Git
item.description: In the previous step we’ve set up a directus project. Now we want to export our schema when we change it. Add a new script to directus-app/package.json: { "name": "directus-app", ... "scripts": { ... "dump": "run-p dump:**", "dump:schema": "directus schema snapshot -y ./schema.yml" } } And add the forwarder to the root package.json: { "private": true, ... "scripts": { ... "dump": "wsrun -m dump" }, ... } Now run yarn dump to save your schema to directus-app/schema.

item.title: Create an Extension
item.description: Now let’s add some functionality to Directus in the form of an extension. TODO: I still have to write a section actually developing the extension. First we need to generate our extension files: yarn create directus-extension Choose the extension type: bundle Choose a name for the extension: directus-extension-example It is important to prefix your extension name with directus-extension-. If you don’t, Directus will not load your extension. And add this new package to your root package.
